concept.title: Quick Start Step 4:
concept.shortdesc: During this step you will use Terraform to create a cluster on .

ol.li: Decompress the file into a convenient directory.
Navigate to the directory and ensure that it contains a .tfvars file. Your .tfvars file should contain the credentials and keys for your cluster.
Configure the necessary values in your .tfvars file, using the included overrides.tfvars.sample file as a guide.For more information, see Terraform Variables.

Run the following command:terraform apply -var-file=<myVariables>.tfvars
Terraform creates the necessary security groups and VM instances, installs Docker, and installs the Docker images required to run .If Terraform displays errors, ensure that all variables have values and that the values are correct.At the end of the process, Terraform displays the URL of the core, formatted using the xip.io wildcard DNS, for example:API endpoint: http://api.15.125.91.46.xip.ioYou will need this URL to use the Cloud Foundry CLI. You can also run the terraform show command to see detailed information about the core.Exploring the Core
After the Docker image is deployed as an instance on , you can view the instance and its security groups on :
To view the instance, click Project Compute Instances .
To view the security group, clicking Project Computer Access and Security .Ensure that all three security groups are available, for example cluster1-SSH, cluster-1-Router, and cluster-1-Internal

Navigate to the core URL in your browser.When you first connect to the core URL, your browser may warn you that the console is attempting to use a self-signed certificate, or that the site is not trusted. You can safely ignore these warnings or add the certificate to your certificate store.
Log into the console using the email and password you specified when you created the cluster.
